column1: Arecibo is located in the Northern Coastal Plain region of Puerto Rico
column2: extending inland into the Karst region. It lies south of the Atlantic Ocean; north of Utuado; east of Hatillo; and west of Barceloneta and Florida. The city occupies an area of 127 square miles (330 km2)
column5: is water.The Rio Grande de Arecibo is the main river in the municipality
column6: running through the middle of it. South of the municipality

column9: a primary source of water for Northern Puerto Rico. Several rivers feed the Rio Grande
column10: including the Tanama River. Caño Santiago is an artificial canal created in the 19th century by partially diverting the Tanama River's waters tobarrios a small temporary stream
column11: to supply water to poor neighborhoods in Arecibo
column12: discharging into the Arecibo River near its own mouth. In the 1950s it was modified to pass slightly more south of the city center. Poor maintenance
column13: sediment and pollution has turned the canal once again into a temporary stream. East of the river lies Caño Tiburones
column14: an important marshland area that provides habitat for many kinds of birds and wildlife.

column1: Arecibo has two forest reserves. Cambalache State Forest is located along the Barceloneta city limits
column2: while Rio Abajo State Forest is located between Arecibo and Utuado. Caves include Cueva Ventana

column4: and La Cueva del Indio (Cave of the Indian)
column5: where paintings made by prehistoric indigenous peoples have been seen.

column1: Arecibo HarborThe Arecibo Harbor is managed by the Puerto Rico Ports Authority.
Cathedral of Saint Philip the Apostle
Arecibo is one of the oldest colonial towns in Puerto Rico (1616). Among its historic buildings is the Cathedral of Saint Phillip Apostle
column2: built beginning in the late 18th century. The first church
column3: built in the middle of the 17th century
column4: was destroyed by an earthquake in 1787. Construction of its replacement began soon after
column5: although it was not completed until 1846. Four days after its dedication
column6: an earthquake seriously damaged it. Repairs were not completed until 1882. The 1918 earthquake damaged the vault so badly that it was replaced by a flat concrete roof; a vaulted ceiling of composition board was placed inside.

column1: The cathedral of Arecibo is Puerto Rico's second-largest church after the Cathedral of San Juan. The plan is rectangular with three naves; the side naves are cut short to allow large flanking chapels
column2: which occupy almost half the length of the church. The apse is semicircular
column3: and has an unusual half-dome covering it. The facade is a triangular composition of three stages. The top stage
column4: a short central tower
column6: according to local architects and historians. Neoclassic ornamentation is used in an academic fashion on the lowest stage
column7: but the other two show a less traditional use of bands and pilasters. The Renaissance-style windows are uncommon in Puerto Rican churches
column8: but the central tower over the entrance is a common motif used throughout the island.

column1: The City Hall of Arecibo is typical of these regional seats of government. It is relatively modest in size
column2: of stuccoed masonry
column4: having a pedimented center pavilion which projects slightly. The lower story is rusticated
column5: with arched openings; the three doorways in the center giving the effect of a loggia. The upper windows all have segmental pediments and balconies; the central trio share one long balcony. Architectural detailing is modest
column6: but the building is graceful and charming.

column1: Punta Los Morrillos LighthouseIn 1898 the Spaniards built the Arecibo Lighthouse. It was automated in 1964 and is still in use. A small park
column2: Arecibo Lighthouse and Historical Park

column1: Arecibo ObservatoryThe Arecibo Observatory is the largest single-unit radio telescope ever constructed and one of the world's most powerful radar-radio telescopes. The observatory's purpose is to support scientific studies. It has attracted several Hollywood directors who have filmed there; most recently GoldenEye and Contact. The radio telescope was used in 1974 to send the Arecibo message to space.

column1: All municipalities in Puerto Rico are administered by a mayor
column2: elected every four years. The current mayor of Arecibo is Carlos Molina
column3: of the New Progressive Party (PNP). He was elected at the 2012 general elections.

column1: The city belongs to the Puerto Rico Senatorial district III
column2: which is represented by two Senators. In 2008
column3: José Emilio González and Angel Martínez were elected as District Senators.

column1: The flag of Arecibo derives its composition and colors from the coat of arms of the city. It is divided vertically in two equal parts. The left side is blue having a belt that stands for "Captain Correa"
column2: a local military hero from Spanish times. The right side is made up of blue and yellow diamonds alternating in a checkerboard pattern referring to the coat of arms of Felipe de Beaumont y Navarra governor of Puerto Rico (1614–1620) and founder of the city. The crown represents The Cacique (chieftain) Arasibo (Fransico Jamaica Arasibo). The turtles represent the ancientness of the city (the third city of Puerto Rico) also because of the indigenous people of the region and that the hunting of turtles was a source of wealth. The towers were a form to describe the population of a settlement. Three towers represent a municipality
column4: and five towers represent a city.

column1: The shield is divided by diagonal lines in golden and blue rhombuses with a blue stripe in the superior part
column2: in which resides an opened five-point crown and which is adorned with drawings characterizing the art of the Taínos. The people of Arecibo also honored Captain Antonio de los Reyes Correa by including a gold colored belt in their coat of arms with the words "Muy Leal"
column4: in representation of Correa. This combination of symbols represents the Indian Cacique (Chieftain) from whom the population's name derives
column5: the governor that erected the town and the hero Captain Correa who defended the town from a British invasion.

column1: Arecibo is known as "La Villa del Capitán Correa" (Captain Correa's Villa) after the Puerto Rican hero Captain Antonio de los Reyes Correa of the Spanish Army
column2: who drove off a British Navy invasion by ambushing forces led by rear-admiral William Whetstone. Arecibo is also known as "El Diamante Del Norte" (The Diamond of the North).

column1: Arecibo is home to several public and private schools distributed through several regions. Public education is handled by the State Department of Education.
There are also several colleges and universities located in the city. Some of them are:
University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo
Pontifical Catholic University of Puerto Rico
Universidad del EsteIt also has several other technical institutions like the National College of Business and Technology and the ICPR Junior College.
The following is a list of notable people from Arecibo:
Antonio de los Reyes Correa – military hero
Cayetano Coll y Cuchí – the first President of Puerto Rico House of Representatives
Francisco Gonzalo Marín – poet who fought for Cuba's independence
José Coll y Cuchí – politician; founder of Puerto Rican Nationalist Party
Luisa Capetillo – union leader/civil rights activist
Melba Acosta – Secretary of Treasury of PR
